dialogue.statement: Hello! It's great to have you here. How have things been going for you lately?
Hey. It's been a bit overwhelming, to be honest. I'm just trying to wrap my head around starting community college and all the stuff that comes with it.
Starting community college can definitely feel overwhelming with so many new experiences and responsibilities. What aspects are you finding most challenging right now?
client(exploring): I'm mostly worried about missing out on the "college experience" and not having much of a social life. Plus, I'm stressing about how far the college is and how I'm gonna get there.

Balancing new responsibilities and desires can be tough. You might feel torn between wanting that full "college experience" and the practical challenges like transportation. What's been on your mind regarding the social aspect and the commute?

client(exploring): Honestly, I'm just scared I won't make any friends or fit in since I imagine the crowd being so different at community college. And the commute is stressing me out because it's just so far and feels like a huge hassle without reliable transportation.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared a rich narrative of their feelings and concerns surrounding community college, including both their fears about missing the traditional college experience and logistical challenges like transportation. They have expressed regret about past academic decisions and a desire for change and growth. The rapport is evident, and the client is open to exploring solutions. It's a good point to transition to Guiding, focusing on motivations and potential solutions. The detailed context and emotional depth provided will facilitate evoking Change Talk. What worked well was summarizing the client's multifaceted concerns, which reinforced empathy and understanding.

dialogue.statement: Navigating these concerns shows how much you care about making the most of this new chapter. How do you think overcoming the transportation issue might impact your experience and connection with others at college?

client(guiding): If I could sort out the transportation, I'd probably be less stressed and more open to meeting people. It'd make me feel more in control, and maybe I'd have more energy and time to focus on building a social life.

Recognizing how transportation affects your stress levels and social opportunities shows great insight. What would life look like if you felt more in control and had the energy to focus on building those connections?
client(guiding): If I felt more in control, I think I'd be more confident and relaxed. I'd probably try to join some clubs or get involved in campus activities to meet people and make friends.
That vision of confidence and involvement in campus life sounds exciting and rewarding. How does thinking about joining clubs or activities align with your goals for college and your personal growth?

client(guiding): Well, it aligns pretty well because I really want to make the most of my time at college, even if it's at a community college. Getting involved in clubs or activities could help me grow personally and socially, and maybe even help me feel a bit more like I'm getting that "college experience" I want.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified a specific change goal of overcoming transportation issues to facilitate social connections and achieve their desired college experience. Change Talk is evident in their desire to join clubs and activities, aligning with personal growth goals. The client envisions increased confidence and social involvement, showing a shift towards readiness for change. The discrepancy between current concerns and desired outcomes has been explored, and the client has reacted to summaries with further insights. It's time to collaboratively develop action plans and address barriers. Reflecting on the guiding phase, affirming the client's insight and vision for the future helped build momentum toward readiness for change.

dialogue.statement: Therapist(choosing): It's fantastic to hear how clearly you've identified ways to enhance your college experience. Considering your goals, one option might be to research nearby clubs or activities that interest you. Another could be exploring transportation solutions, like carpooling or public transit. Which of these steps feels like a good starting point for you, or is there another idea that comes to mind?

client(choosing): I think looking into clubs or activities is a good starting point. It'll help me see what interests are out there and who I might connect with. I'll also try to explore some public transit options to make the commute less of a headache.

Both steps sound proactive and empowering as you navigate this new stage. How might you go about researching these clubs and activities, and what initial steps could you take to explore public transit options?

client(choosing): I guess I could start by checking out the college's website or asking around about clubs or events they have. For public transit, maybe I'll look up bus routes online or see if there's anyone I know who's familiar with the area and can help me figure it out.

Those are practical and resourceful approaches to start exploring your options. Checking the college's website or asking others about clubs can lead you to exciting opportunities to meet people with similar interests. For public transit, researching bus routes online or seeking advice from someone familiar with the area could offer clarity and reduce stress. How do you feel about setting a timeline for yourself to start these actions, and how would you like to keep track of your progress?

client(deciding): I think setting a timeline could help me stay on track and not procrastinate. Maybe I could aim to have some solid information on clubs and transit options by the end of next week. I could keep a checklist or notes on my phone to track what I've done and what still needs attention.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a clear action plan to explore clubs and public transit, and has agreed on self-monitoring through a checklist, indicating readiness for change. The client demonstrates commitment by setting a timeline and discussing the impact on their social connections and control over their situation. Reflective and affirming statements have helped the client articulate these steps confidently. They appear ready to begin implementing these actions, suggesting they are prepared to move forward. OARS feedback: The process of identifying and planning actionable steps worked effectively, building the client's confidence and motivation to engage in college life actively. Continued support in self-monitoring and adjusting plans as needed will be beneficial.

dialogue.statement: Creating a timeline to stay on top of these actions sounds like a smart move. Aiming to gather information by the end of next week gives you a clear, manageable goal to work towards. Keeping a checklist on your phone is a practical way to monitor your progress and celebrate each step forward. It's wonderful to see how you're taking charge of your college experience. Remember, I'm here to support you as you explore these new avenues. Looking forward to hearing how things develop for you.
Thanks, that means a lot. I'll definitely let you know how it goes, and I appreciate having your support as I figure things out.

statement.reasoning: The client has developed a proactive plan, incorporating timelines and strategies to address their primary concern. Summary and next steps have been discussed, aligning with termination goals. Great engagement and ownership were shown in planning.

concern:
title: afraid of no college experience at cc pls don’t hate
i start my freshmen year of community college this month and im looking forward to it but also not since i already know the bad that comes from it. for ex: 

•no social life 
•NO COLLEGE EXPERIENCE 
•possibility of having a full class with middle aged parents/ business workers that randomly wanted to be in school again
• watching all my friends and mutuals have fun at their university that i also wanna attend to etc.
•being stuck in my room doing nothing etc 

i personally want to go to community for just one year then transfer and i know it’s harder that way if you don’t get your full 60 credits and transfer as a junior but why would i want to waste all my time at cc and possibly only have 1.5 years to enjoy myself at a uni??? community isn’t best for me but im only doing it because my high school gpa would not have gotten me into a uni and i do regret it because i skipped a lot or had very very bad mental health days so now i have to deal with the consequences and so community is really my only route for right now. and it sucks knowing that I won’t have the experience i want I know you’re thinking “the experience isn’t the main important thing just transfer in 2 years it’s not big deal plUs yOuR SavIng moNey” yeah I’ve read other reddit threads of teens expressing their same feelings that i have and it’s a bunch of the middle aged adults saying the same thing. let’s be honest here im 18 and so are the other peers that feel this way that are around the ages of 17-23 ofc we want to live a little and are pissed about having to be at community while everyone else is having fun. also you may know this but for some people university is their only escape route from home/toxic homes/ or just tired of being in their city cause they’ve been their all they’re life. it’s hardening to see and also i don’t live close to my community at all so it’s gonna be HELL trying to get there and back, my parents don’t own a car and i don’t trust a uber either. i just know this is gonna be one hell of a first year. any advice on how to deal through this? how i can make friends easier? IF i do end up having to do 2 years how should i get through it? what did you do?
